content: How can I help you today?
I’ve been having trouble sleeping, and my partner thought it might help to talk to someone about it. I’m not really sure where to start though.

Thank you for sharing that. Trouble sleeping can be frustrating and can affect so many aspects of daily life. It's great that you're open to talking about it. What’s been going on with your sleep lately?

I just can’t shut my brain off at night. There’s so much stress at work, and I’m scared about possibly losing my job, especially with how things have been in the economy. I usually end up scrolling on my phone to distract myself, but it doesn't really help—it just makes everything worse.

It sounds like there's a lot weighing on your mind right now, with work stress and those worries about job security. That’s a lot to carry, especially at night when everything feels more intense. Swiping through your phone might feel like a temporary escape, but it seems like it’s adding to the struggle rather than easing it. What else have you noticed about what’s been keeping you up?

I mean, it’s really just the stress. I keep thinking about all the ways things could go wrong—getting fired, not being able to pay the bills, letting my family down. And then I get even more worked up because I know I should be sleeping to deal with it all, but I can’t. It feels like a cycle I can’t break.

That sounds overwhelming—being stuck in a cycle of stress and worry, where even trying to rest ends up feeling like one more stressor. Those fears about your job and family are heavy, and it makes sense that they might feel hard to escape. With all of this going on, what does sleep mean to you right now?

Sleep feels like something I desperately need but can’t seem to get. It’s almost like a reminder of how much I’m struggling to hold everything together. I know I’d feel better and think more clearly if I could sleep, but no matter how much I want that, it just doesn't happen.

Sleep feels like the key to getting back on track, yet it’s also tied to the pressure you’re feeling. Wanting it so badly but not being able to achieve it seems to add to the stress you’re already carrying. It sounds like you really value being able to think clearly and feel more in control. What have you tried so far to work through this?

It feels like I’ve tried everything, but nothing really sticks. I’ve thought about putting my phone away before bed, but honestly, it’s so hard to resist when my mind is racing. I’ve tried deep breathing a few times, but I usually just give up because my thoughts keep creeping back in.

It’s tough when it feels like nothing works, especially when you’re trying to quiet your mind and it keeps pulling you back into those racing thoughts. Putting your phone away or practicing deep breathing are ideas that show you’re already thinking about ways to tackle this, even if they haven’t felt effective yet. What keeps you coming back to these strategies or considering them again?

I guess it’s because I know they’re probably the right things to do, even if they’re hard. I feel like if I could just stick with them, maybe I'd see some improvement, but I get frustrated when they don’t work right away. It’s hard to stay motivated when everything feels so out of control.

It sounds like you see the potential in those strategies, even though sticking with them hasn’t been easy—especially when frustration sets in. Feeling like so much is out of control right now makes it harder to stay motivated, but recognizing that these steps could help shows a lot of hope and determination from you. What do you think could make it easier to stick with them or try something new?

Honestly, I don’t know. It just feels like such an uphill battle, and I’m already so drained from everything else. Maybe if I had something really simple to start with or a way to feel like it’s actually making a difference, that might help. But it’s hard to even know where to begin.

The idea of starting with something simple and feeling like it makes a real impact sounds like a big step in the right direction. It shows you’re willing to explore ways to take control, even in the middle of everything you’re dealing with. Before we think about possibilities, is there anything else you’d like to share or talk through about what’s been making sleep so difficult?
No, I think I’ve said everything that’s been on my mind. I’m open to hearing suggestions, even if I’m not feeling super confident about it all yet.

Thank you for being open and for sharing everything you’ve been navigating—it takes strength to talk through these challenges. To recap, you’ve expressed that stress is keeping your mind busy at night, and although you’ve tried strategies like putting your phone away or deep breathing, sticking with them has been tough. You’re looking for something simple to start with and would like to feel small signs of progress to help stay motivated. Would it be okay to explore possible ideas together now?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
